abstract: This executive brief summarizes a 2025 experimental study on how sustainable cues, pack formats, and price context influence non-alcoholic beer selection across key shopper segments. The report synthesizes preference shares, sentiment feedback, and discrepancy analysis to guide portfolio and messaging strategy.
context: The study focused on non-alcoholic beer selections in controlled digital shopping tasks.
Respondents evaluated brand options under varying price and multi-brand scenarios.

researchQuestions.text: How do sustainability signals change selection rates in 1v1 and multi-brand tasks?
Which shopper segments consistently exceed defined pick-rate thresholds?

hypotheses.text: Sustainability cues increase mother-brand pick rates in no-price scenarios.
Price parity reduces the pick-rate gap between mother brands and challengers.
Higher activity shoppers over-index on Heineken pick rate thresholds.

keyTakeaways.text: Preference shifts are largest when sustainability cues are paired with familiar packaging.
Multi-brand contexts dampen absolute pick rates but improve differentiation.
A minority of segments cross the 75% threshold, highlighting targeted opportunity.
Sentiment drivers cluster around taste expectations and availability signals.
